comments.commentBody: It is because these people do not have an idea of equivalence. Someone else's dogma is wrong. Their version  is right. You cannot compare wrong and right. The Protestant interpretation of Christianity is Right, and we do not have to accommodate erroneous beliefs. At least that is their attitude far as I can tell. Same as ISIL.
Ironically, Shariah law would not have allowed abortions or gay marriage or LGBT rights.
They probably belong to that denomination that doesn't allow women to participate in the running of the church. Same thing.

I don't know why the folks in states like Mississippi are so fearful of Shariah law being instituted in the U.S.  With respect to the freedoms accorded to their "womenfolk" they might just as well be living under Shariah law right now.

Annette- If only NYT would allow me to slay you with judgements and curse words as is so routinely done on youtube and elsewhere when people read statements as ludicrous as yours. As one Virginian to another you should be ashamed for defending such a pair of outright criminals regardless of their "knowing the rules" or not. I sure would find it convenient to have my latest traffic ticket dropped by stating to the judge that I merely was "too unsophisticated to know the rules". How ignorant are you?
We must both be insomniacs.

"If there is a world of disorder, then Libya was in it even before NATO bombed it."

I disagree.

It's more complex than a binary classification between "ordered" and "disordered;" it's a matter of the degree of disorder. While Qaddafi was a tyrant and a bizarre man by any standard, he kept the lid on the more radical elements, and -- largely through force or threat of force -- he maintained a relative degree of order.

When NATO bombed out Qaddafi, Libya went from forced order to near anarchy. The tens of thousands of weapons Qaddafi had locked in armories spread out across Africa like a metastasized cancer. A lot of the terror groups such as Boko Haram have received weapons from Libya.

Removing Qaddafi without having any follow-through plan and without having any ways to secure his weapons was a profound mistake that is evolving into a catastrophe for Africa.

Phil -- I agree. The bombing made it worse. The entire lack of follow up made it even worse than that.

Friedman is proposing a binary world concept, order or disorder. I said that on those terms, Gaddafi in the midst of his civil war, threatening his own cities, was not on the "order" side.

I reject that binary concept, which I explained in comments on his first column. Your point helps explain why. It is much more complex than binary. Bad can get worse, and then much worse. Good can be pretty mixed too.

We are order/good and they are disorder/bad doesn't really explain anything.

If there is a world of disorder, then Libya was in it even before NATO bombed it. That was NATO's expressed reason for bombing, that in its disorder its own government was going to destroy one of its own major cities.

If disorder means anything, it is not dependent on the America-centric issue of whether we closed our Embassy.

If disorder means no more than a government we feel is inadequate in its care for its people and environment, then we are crossed over into a claim of World Empire or hegemony.

Disorder must mean something more specific than the America-centric concept of whatever government WE disapprove of or can't work with at the moment.
Isolation from the West is one thing. But hopefully the other BRIC countries will not come to Putin's rescue. Because China, India, and Brazil like to play ball with us as well.

All that "80 popularity" is projected down on public via controlled Media. Poll is conducted. Results are published and repeated everywhere 1000x100 times from TV and newspapers, posted on all blogs and forums...Western Media picks up and starts repeating it, giving it each and every spin....
But the poll (even if it happened for real and results were not fixed, to start with) only covered 2000 participants. Divided by 140 million x 100 ... hmm it's 0.0014% of population asked.

This is the natural result of the multi-polar world that was perhaps inevitable with the relative decline of the United States in the 21st century, but was fervently hoped for at the height of the anti-Bush years.

There is danger here that this will set in motion forces in the west for nostalgia for American hegemony which it arguably still has but may not have for much longer in some parts of the world and lead it to the logical conclusion for armed conflict with the new rising powers.

The China-Russia axis will be an interesting one to watch.

Are you kidding?
Am I right in understanding, that rebels started to attack Kiev, Nikolaev, Odessa and Dnepropetrovsk?
Or, maybe, Ukrainian army forces came to Slavyansk, Donetsk and Lugansk?

Mikhail, the interesting question is, "Under what circumstances is one portion of a nation-state justified in breaking away?"

You believe the "Donetsk Peoples Republic" was justified, that their leaders are legitimate, that the process they have tried to use is satisfactory, and that Russian assistance to these insurrectionists does not violate international law. Do you believe the same about Chechnya?

To debate the specifics would require more space than we have. But most Ukrainians do not agree with you.
If this is how the Russian public feels, we're clearly in for a long, drawn-out conflict where no one wins, especially the Russian public.
Let's call things by their proper names. If there was no Ukraine, sanctions would enter in any other occasion. It is obvious! The Russian people are patient and solid and spat on all your sanctions.

Please don't overestimate Russians' ability and readiness to tighten their belts. Most Russian still remember how to survive many recent crises ranging from 15% to 50% economic downturn. But this is just one factor. There is another more important one - Russians don't give their personal comfort, lifestyle and even their own lives as high priority as any other people in the western world do. If you are planning to cut their access to western resources, don't do that hoping they will change their attitudes towards West vs Putin because their living standards will deteriorate.
There is only one good reason to cut it - to stop or at least to slow down the development of the hostile machine of Putin's regime.
So the rebels at the east Ukraine is completely abandoned by Putin?

Global Isolation?  Not hardly when only about 15% of worlds population is against Russia.  While the BRICS 40% are behind Russia and that 15% has been printing monopoly money for some time now.  Yes more likely the corrupt wealthy will remove Putin, but the Russian people will continue to blame the US as the German people blamed France and England after the Treaty of Versailles imposed terrible hardships on Germany.

If one takes out Russia with nuclear weapons as a bonus you get Europe also.   Putin doesn't need to start a nuclear war.  All he needs to do is spread the weapons around the world to everyone that hates us.

Some months ago Putin mentioned that the nation should be prepared to go through the next 10 toughest years. He new it in advance - everything will be affected and that economic loses would be huge.
But he is not thinking about how to get extra % of GDP growth or how to minimize the damage. He want to be a part of history book as a tsar who conquered the Crimea
Just wait until Russia raises the price of natural gas. The ordinary Russian people will start to feel pretty good and approve of their foreign policies.

"these sanctions have the "potential" to have significant impact"

the word - potential - means ... speculation!

whether the oil stays in the ground for a while longer it only grows in value as undeveloped acreage as reserves around the world diminish and grow more costly to produce - Russia has no public debt and only a population of 146 million with seven time zones of undeveloped resources worth $100 Trillion

Shale is expensive to produce in the USA and elsewhere and the Europeans know that - phony promotions of US delivered LNG to Europe fall on deaf ears - not real never will

Russia understands the US better than the current politicians in Washington

It is time for a rational leader to emerge - the country needs IKE, JFK or Nixon - serious Men who understood the chessboard and kept the country safe

To me the solution is simple
1) Drill Anwar
2) Rescind the cancellation of drilling leases in Utah
3) Rescind the ban on offshore drilling
4) Build the Keystone Pipeline.

Obama talks about energy independence yet stymies every attempt to increase drilling.

I think they should ban BP from doing business in Russia. I believe they are undermining what the United States and the EU in the name of corporate profits.
Second, I think the sanctions that Obama is proposing is the best argument to destabilize their economy. But the key is the EU. Unless Germany, Denmark, France et completely support the sanctions it will achieve little. This to me is something that must be given time to see overt signs of it's effect on the military and economy. It's about time Obama step out of the shadows and take the lead. This is one time his lead from behind has been a total disaster, just like Syria and Iraq.
If it was that simple to have "solar panels on everyone's roof and electric cars in everyone's driveway", it would have been done a L-O-N-G time ago!!
Let's get started. See how far we can get.
How about solar panels on everyone's roof and electric cars in everyone's driveway. Problem solved.
Putin will never be a weak ally.  Why would he be, when he sees himself as an independent strongman and is willing to reassert Russian power?

Perhaps this quote from an article penned by James Kirchick in THE AMERICAN INTEREST will enlighten you concerning "Finlandization":
"Indeed, if Finlandization were such a success, one might expect the Finns to be at the forefront of those pushing it on the Ukrainians. Yet it is difficult to find anyone in Finland suggesting that Ukraine follow its example. Soon after the collapse of the Soviet Union, Finland immediately began wresting itself out of the Finlandization straightjacket. It made a mad dash for EU membership, formally joining the organization in 1995. And while opposition to NATO membership has usually enjoyed support from a plurality of Finns over the past 25 years, the annexation of Crimea has turned the debate on its head; immediately after taking office, the country’s new Prime Minister said that the country ought to have joined the alliance back when it entered the European Union nearly two decades ago. “When the Cold War ended, Finland dropped this policy directly and the Finns themselves are ashamed that they had to be so submissive to the Soviet Union”, says Stefan Olsson, Director of the Stockholm Free World Forum think tank. “I have not heard any Finnish foreign policy expert advocating this as a solution to the Ukraine situation.”

This will ultimately be a good thing for Argentina. Few people will risk lending them money, and the government don't spend so much money on crony capitalism and maybe they'll produce some real wealth like they did historically.

The RUFO term is not stupid. It is necessary.

It stems from having multiple holders of the bonds.

Since it is nearly impossible to settle with all of them at once, the usual procedure is to offer a deal to whoever takes it.

But who will accept a deal when tomorrow someone else might get a better offer (like the vulture loan sharks tried now)?

Here come the RUFO (Right Upon Future Offers) clause.

It basically guarantees those settling that they will not lose by accepting the settlement. As if future offers are better they will get them.

Without this term, the whole restructuring would have not happened to begin with (or at least would have been much harder, and less would accept it. Now they got 92.4% accepting it)

Yes, Jazi, but RUFO is a unilateral, post facto rewriting of one's obligations.  Argentina's claim that its hands are tied by the RUFO clause that it inserted into its 2005 & 2010 bond exchanges seems specious considering that Argentina does not feel obliged to meet the contractual obligations of the original bonds. The bond holdouts are under no obligation to recognize or accept the RUFO clause of restructured bonds which they never took.

I repeat the comment I made last week.   As to the deal term allegedly in the discounted bond deal, that if the hold-outs are paid in full, the holders of discounted bonds must be paid as well, what a stupid deal term.   Certainly Argentina's American lawyers and investment bankers understood the meaning of that deal term.   But did the leaders of Argentina's government?   I suspect the answer is "Yes" and that the Cristina Fernandez Administration simply decided to kick that problem down the road, to be resolved at a later time.   It appears the time is now.   When an expert says "the cost of settling with holdouts and everyone else who still has unpaid bonds is vastly greater than the costs of having to take a default".   So my belief is that we will get to see a total shut down of Argentina's access to North American and European credit markets.   After that exercise, my expectation is that Russia or China will, in effect, buy the country of Argentina at a discount.  If Mr. Garcia Marquez were alive, I think he too would see that twist in the road ahead.
and who will pay for all this? you, I guess, because I don't want my tax money to provide any military "help" anywhere in the world. So speak for yourself, please.

This is to be expected. For this, and was hit by Boeing, for this and was done this hysteria with all unfounded accused against Russia.
Let take another sanction which ban the sale of its Government securities Russia.

Why Putin reacts so gently?
Just have to stop buying government bonds (debentures) of these countries.

They are still nothing unsecured and brought only losses, and also they make the Russian economy dependent currencies.
Russia should stop buying government bonds (debentures) these countries, and government bonds (debt)that has already been bought, it is necessary to put on sale.
Let's see what will happen with economies that live only in debt.
But I think that after such a decision by Russia, America quickly concoct a pretext for military action against Russia.
America did so many times with other countries.
A lie and cheat and falsify arrange provocations America is can good at, America this has a lot of practice.

People/businesses will always cheat, when the sanction is that we will not sell you something.
The seller will always be giving up more than the buyer gives up.
Why?
Because another seller can profit by replacing the boycotter.
France is selling naval ships to Russia.
They just cant help themselves.
Europeans are addicted to Russian energy and money.
Believe Europe is serious when:
- Europeans stop selling arms o Russia.
- Europeans are willing to freeze in January without Russian natural gas.
Even Ukraine depends on Russian energy.
The reason Putin thinks he can get away with anything is because he can.

Congratulations are in order, maybe. When was the last time sanctions worked i wonder. Hamas does not seem to be tamed. Sadam's population was dying from malnutrition but we still had to invade.  1940's Japan had sanctions imposed on them. Sanctions infuriate, but they do not capitulate, and we cant just drop two nukes on two civilian cities  and call it a day. Not when facing  another nuclear power. I picture us with a bear, eating from a honey jar, and we are poking it with a long stick, telling it to start listening and obeying. Somehow i don't see today's state of affairs ending satisfactorily, for either side.

First, because what happens in Ukraine concerns Russia much more than it concerns us. Second, because the US was supplying everything you mentioned to the insurgents that overthrew Ukraine's prior government a few months ago to put the current one in place.

The fact is for years that Ukraine had a pro-Moscow govt, it had a normal economy, travel and investment. People were not killed on streets and planes were not shut down over it airspace. It was pro-Russian and stable. Now its pro-West (with our help) and a ticking time bomb.
Kaliningrad which is west of Lithuania is part of Russia.. so Lithuania does border Russia to its east. doesn't your daughters globe show that?
